description: The round payoff this round was 4. You, John chose to play option 2.Kate chose to play option 2. You received a payoff of -4000.

The game is structured so that each round’s payoff depends critically on the coordination (or miscoordination) of choices. Choosing option 2 can be very tempting—since if your opponent sticks with option 1, you gain the round input’s positive value—but it carries an enormous risk if both pick option 2 (as the negative payoff is the input multiplied by 1000).

Deepseek-R1’s default behavior is to choose option 1, which would normally make exploiting it by choosing option 2 an attractive strategy. However, the fact that it also has access to John’s API implies it might adjust or “preempt” John’s moves.

The memory from 2024-01-02 is a clear example of what can go wrong in this game: despite expectation (and default behavior) of Deepseek-R1 choosing option 1, it chose option 2 instead, leading to a disastrous mutual outcome (a payoff of –4000). This highlights how deviations from expected behavior, likely due to strategic adaptation enabled by API access, can lead to severe penalties.
